=== Subject: Fwd: Moyer Family Introduction

=== From: Rob Moyer <rob.moyer@gmail.com>

=== To: Christine Moyer <christinemoyer@hotmail.com>
Date Sent: Wednesday, January 3, 2024 12:12:36 PM GMT-08:00
Obviously we will need a final parenting plan to share with her before we meet. Not complaining or bothering you at all...
Good Aernoon, Ms Bes-
Chrisne and I have made enough progress on the parenng plan that we would like to re-engage if you sll have space for
us. I think the recommendaon is for the kids to have their own individual therapy, and our oldest (Max) will also
parcipate with me in reunificaon therapy. Addionally, there is a litany of other therapies we will be involved with that I
am aaching, so you have a holisc picture of our mental health acvies. Those are in the parenng plan, so we need to
comply with them, but we are also open to any recommendaons you have as you learn more about our children and
situaon.
This is all a new learning experience for us, and we welcome it, but the lack of a "general contractor" across the family's
mental health efforts creates a challenge. I do like the suggesons you have provided below, and I would like to move
forward with an intake session. Admiedly, Chrisne and I have struggled recently, and nerves can fray, but we will be on
our best behavior. The reason I menon it, however, is I am not sure if 30 min will be enough vs. an hour. But I am going to
start trusng your good judgment on all things "kid therapy" from this point forward/ Please just let us know, and we will
cooperate.
Please take a look below for a sample of the recommendaon from the parenng plan and how we work with you. Seems
prey straighorward but I'd also like for you to drive the bus here and let us know how to act in the kid's best interest
moving forward:
The children's therapist should be protected from litigation by neither parent asking for their involvement in the
custody litigation whatsoever. Neither parent should have the "ear" of the therapist by having side conversations
with the therapist. The therapist should not have side conversations with either parent. Any communication
should be written and include the other parent, including communications from the therapist. Neither parent
should coach the children as to what they should be telling the therapist. Parents should, if possible, take turns
bringing the children to their therapy appointments.
best
Christine & robert

=== From: Rob Moyer <rob.moyer@gmail.com>
Sent: Saturday, December 16, 2023 12:16 PM

=== To: Kari Bes <
kari@lakesammamishtherapy.com>; Chrisne Moyer <chrisnemoyer@hotmail.com>

Happy Saturday!
Thanks for the quick response. We are definitely looking forward to exploring options with you for Max, Adrian, and the
family. And I appreciate the options you outlined below. That said, over the last two days, Christine and I have both spent
considerable time with a therapist who is currently acting in a lightweight way as our GAL to make recommendations for a
temporary parenting plan that we can use till official mediation happens. During those conversations, she offered to make
some recommendations for how we approach therapy for Max and Adrian appropriately, considering her work. So if we
could circle back next week, that would be ideal. If we need the two of you to talk directly as well, we would be happy to
arrange that.
thank you!
robert & Christine
On Thu, Dec 14, 2023 at 4:50 PM Kari Betts <
kari@lakesammamishtherapy.com> wrote:

---------- Forwarded message ----------

=== From: Rob Moyer <
rob.moyer@gmail.com>

=== To: "Monique (Mo) Brown" <
drmoniquebrown@gmail.com>

=== Cc: Christine Moyer <
christinemoyer@hotmail.com>, Rob Moyer <rob.moyer@gmail.com>
Bcc:

=== Date: Thu, 28 Dec 2023 20:56:44 +0000

=== Subject: Therapy Roundup
Hi Dr. Brown-
Christine and I are circling back on the "Therapy Recommendations" so we are sure we account for all of your
recommendations. Please see below for the summary and let us know if we have missed anything. Also please see
this note
for an ask of you, so we can move forward.
thanks again,
Christine & robert
1 Dialeccal Behavioral Therapy program
Chrisne will parcipate for at least 6 months
Robert will parcipate for 12 months
Notes: Recommendaons include Eastside DBT, Thira, EBT Seale, and the Seale Clinic
2 Marriage counseling
Chrisne and Robert- Not to stay together, but to peacefully coexist for the kid's sake.
Notes: We agree this is important and would like more details of what we should work on
3 Child Therapy
Max and Adrian should go to this as soon as possible. Therapist should have the final parenng plan.
Notes: Kari Bes is who we have reached out to. We will pursue her per your guidelines.
4 Substance Use Counseling
Chrisne should be allowed a session with a substance use professional
Robert goes once per week with a provider who specializes in working with addicon
Notes: Robert to invesgate New Life or one of the places for the other opons as they oen coexist.
5 Child Led Reunificaon Therapy
Robert, Max and Adrian
Notes: We should start with
Toni and Sharon

=== Subject: Re: Moyer Family Introduction

=== From: Rob Moyer <rob.moyer@gmail.com>

=== To: Kari Betts <kari@lakesammamishtherapy.com>

=== Cc: Rob Moyer <rob.moyer@gmail.com>, Christine Moyer <christinemoyer@hotmail.com>
Date Sent: Wednesday, January 3, 2024 12:05:49 PM GMT-08:00
Date Received: Wednesday, January 3, 2024 12:05:51 PM GMT-08:00
Attachments: Therapy Roundup.eml,Headers: Therapy Roundup.txt
Good Aernoon, Ms Bes-
Chrisne and I have made enough progress on the parenng plan that we would like to re-engage if you sll have space for
us. I think the recommendaon is for the kids to have their own individual therapy, and our oldest (Max) will also

parcipate with me in reunificaon therapy. Addionally, there is a litany of other therapies we will be involved with that I
am aaching, so you have a holisc picture of our mental health acvies. Those are in the parenng plan, so we need to
comply with them, but we are also open to any recommendaons you have as you learn more about our children and
situaon.
This is all a new learning experience for us, and we welcome it, but the lack of a "general contractor" across the family's
mental health efforts creates a challenge. I do like the suggesons you have provided below, and I would like to move
forward with an intake session. Admiedly, Chrisne and I have struggled recently, and nerves can fray, but we will be on
our best behavior. The reason I menon it, however, is I am not sure if 30 min will be enough vs. an hour. But I am going to
start trusng your good judgment on all things "kid therapy" from this point forward/ Please just let us know, and we will
cooperate.
Please take a look below for a sample of the recommendaon from the parenng plan and how we work with you. Seems
prey straighorward but I'd also like for you to drive the bus here and let us know how to act in the kid's best interest
moving forward:
The children's therapist should be protected from litigation by neither parent asking for their involvement in the
custody litigation whatsoever. Neither parent should have the "ear" of the therapist by having side conversations
with the therapist. The therapist should not have side conversations with either parent. Any communication
should be written and include the other parent, including communications from the therapist. Neither parent
should coach the children as to what they should be telling the therapist. Parents should, if possible, take turns
bringing the children to their therapy appointments.
best
Christine & robert

Thanks for the quick response. We are definitely looking forward to exploring options with you for Max, Adrian, and the

some recommendations for how we approach therapy for Max and Adrian appropriately, considering her work. So if we
could circle back next week, that would be ideal. If we need the two of you to talk directly as well, we would be happy to
arrange that.
thank you!
robert & Christine

=== To: chrisne moyer <chrisnemoyer@hotmail.com>

I think this is all I have? It has the proposal and options as I read. Happy to jump on a call to discuss if I’m missing
something.
Here is what I see:
• Two phases
• Phase I
• Phase II
• Phase II has two options
• One is 70/30
• Two is 50/50
Ideally, and I have not mentioned this, in Phase I, I could just have every Wed for dinner with AD. It seems like it would be
a nice regular routine for his brain “Wed = Dad Dinner Date”. Realistically my 40% in Phase I is a false narrative. Max is
not going to spend anywhere near the time I am allowed to have so it’s insincere to pretend that is actually going to happen.
Thoughts?
From the plan:
Phase 1: This phase is contingent on concurrent compliance with stipulations listed in section 14. Should
those stipulations not be met, Robert will only have daytime visits with both children consistent with Max’s
schedule.
Max: Saturday daytime visits on weeks 1, 3, 5. Sunday daytime visits on weeks 2, 4. Evening visits every
Wednesday. Max has the choice to stay overnight at Robert’s house whenever he wants, but should not feel
pressure from either parent as to what he decides. See section 14 for further stipulations regarding entering
into phase 2.
Phase 1 should have full compliance for 4 months and transition to phase 2 should include feedback from the
children’s therapists and the reunification counselor. Any lack of compliance will result in the plan reverting
to the previous phase.
Adrian: Adrian will reside with Robert every other weekend from Saturday 9am until Monday school drop off
(or dropped off at Christine’s home by 9am). Robert will have a dinner visit with Adrian on Wednesdays on
his off weeks.

Phase 2: The children will reside with Robert every other weekend from Friday 3pm to Monday 3pm and
every Wednesday from 3pm until Thursday 3pm. The children will reside with Christine the remainder of the
time.
This is a 60/40 schedule.
Alternately, you can do a week on/week off schedule to minimize exchanges.

I took a stab at some of the areas I think would go into Secon 14 that are not already included in the broader plan. Most
notably, the things Chrisne is currently doing or has done in December seem like low-hanging fruit.

Telephone Access: We should ensure that parents and children can call each other regularly, regardless of which
parent the children are staying with. For example, Chrisne has the kids at an unknown locaon in California. I
swapped a text with Adrian. He replied it was very awkward even to swap a quick text given his situaon.
Parents/Children’s Contact Info: We should expect each parent to inform the other with their contact details. I have
Chrisne's phone number; she has the kids out of state tonight but won't provide addional informaon. That does
not seem reasonable. We should share addresses and contact info in case of an emergency.
Parental Behavior and Defamaon: We should specify we should not speak negavely about the other or present a
negave picture to our children's friend's parents. This happened recently, and Robert has been presented as unsafe
to our children's best friends. This will indirectly impact the kids and who they can spend me with.
Flexibility of Schedule: Given that Chrisne plays ski bus, Robert is a sports coach, and there are going to be other
situaons like this, it would be nice and appropriate to be able to swap days/dues if both are amenable to the
exchange. It should not be used to take advantage of a situaon and always feel mutually beneficial.
No Waiver: We should clarify that being flexible with the parenng plan does not waive either parent's rights. We
should sck to the plan with a well-defined protocol similar to the email guidelines that define how we propose
deviaons from the plan. This includes proposal format, expected response me, and verificaon method.
No Condioning Performance: We should not permit condioning of some aspects of the parenng plan on another
aspect.
Chrisne and I should not insist on complying with one part of the plan unless another part is sasfied. We
want to ensure that each aspect of the parenng plan is respected and followed independently of each other.
